element_texts.text: Completed

July 17. 1866. Elyria Tuesday Eve.

My Dearest
I have just written a letter to Rev J. N. Newton in reply to one from him asking for coal. Last night wrote one to L.L. Jenkins in reply to one from him. He is established at Boston you know. Your letter of the 13th came to hand this evening. The Boys and myself wrote a big letter to you Sunday night, mailed yesterday morning, which after some hesitation I directed to Pembroke;  thinking it would not get around before Thursday, and that by that time you would be there rather than at Yarmouth. I wrote much about going East, or rather not going, and mostly concluding it was hardly best to try to go. If I went I should hardly feel like staying more than the finest possible day, to go and come in, and perhaps it would hardly be worth the while if you could come back alone or with Samuel or somehow. 
There would seem to be no difficulty about the Children, or about any one of them in particular at any rate. Wilder could go up to Charles'. or over to Mr. Twiss, Charley to Dr. DeWitts or half a dozen other places; he has a first class invitation to go down to Boyds' on the Lake Shore. Geo Boyd you know is an especial Chum of his. Anna could stay at Twiss' or anywhere else; would be good and slight trouble any where; and Little Don John, could go to Eliab, or Eliza could take
Completed

the best of care of him here. And yes somehow collectively I do not feel a bit like learning them. Perhaps however I may start off in a hurry  some day, but it is very doubtful. 
Glad to hear of May's well doing. I must write to her dear self specially, I think. 
Took Anna tonight over to Mr. Twiss by way of Experiment. Do not know how it will Answer. Little John wanted "Nanny" "Nanny" very frequently after she was. I suspect he will be sort of lonesome and fretting for her. 
You speak of dry weather for our wet.  You need not say much now on that score. It cleared off here in Monday July 9th. Since then a Cloudless sky, the heat well the Thermometer any where but in the ice houses has ranged from 90 to 100, and the Drougth already begins to be severe! Tonight a few cloudy minutes and a bare sprinkle seem to have cooled the air a little.

                                                                                                   Undeniably 
                                                                                                                    Isaac.

Isaac July 17 1866
Completed

Isaac 
                                                                                                 July 19 1866  
                                                                                                                    Elyria, July 19 1866 

My Dearest 

          Your letter to Charley came to hand tonight. Charley & Wilder had gone over to Mr Twiss to see Anna to carry her some clothes or lead her home as might be. She went over there on Tuesday P.M. I should not see the boys, (as it was meeting night) until tomorrow morning. So I thought I might as well read the letter myself. And now perhaps I may as well answer it.Though I do not know it it needs special answer, except that we are especially glad to have you write to us often and particularly.
Completed

It is comfortably cool for a day or two past, Cloudy though with very little rain, just enough yesterday afternoon to wet my hay; the Three acre meadow beyond the Henson house was mowed by a morning machine yesterday morning. The sun did not come out and it did not dry enough to take up and it got wet before night. Today the boys & myself, have worked over it most of the afternoon & Charles & his three boys two or three hours and it is now nicely in a little less than 150 cocks. (on which there is nice smart rain now
The Cooler weather is nice for the Children, John feels much better for it and sleeps like a top, besides needing hardly any care all day. During the very warm weather he was red & itching all over
Other people I guess feel better too judging from the Meetings. Prayer
Completed

Meetings last week & week before quite thin. Tonight the room quite full and a very good meeting. Just six prayers and six exhortations, besides a few remarks of Mr Wilbur. 

Charley will be greatly pleased at his letters, and Wilder will make a comical face because he has not one. Rev Geo A Perkins I very well remember. Though seeing his name occasionally of late I hardly knew if it was the same, slender, pale faced hard student. 

Do I understand that you wanted another picture of John tried for? We thought that was about right. 
Then are you going back from Pembroke & Dunbarton?

Samuel left here this morning. I was sorry it happened so you were gone from Yarmouth, the last part
Completed

of this this and first of next. 
Samuel might have called at Yarmouth if you had been to be there. I might have sent some money to you by him. You might have gone on with him to go to Brownville to visit a little then. As it is so doubtful about my going on at all, or if I should about my stopping to visit. And judging from a letter Charles received from Almeda yesterday there is little or no prospect of her coming West this fall. She said she could not at any rate come with Samuel for she could not at all travel in hot weather. 
And the state of Hattie's (James' Wife's) health was such it was very doubtful if she could leave at all. She is strickened? with Consumption I guess.

                                                                Sincerely, 
                                                                          Isaac.
Completed

Elyria, July 22 1866

Isaac
July 22, 1866
Very Dearest
Yours of the 18th inst came to hand last night. Your letters seem to come this way quicker than ours get to you do they not.  I mailed two letters last week or three to Pembroke. I do not know whether they will get there while you are there or not.  I do not understand from your letter just how long you are going to stay in New Hampshire - especially uner the new arrangement - As George does not go with you. 
It seems to have happened just wrong in some respects about the time of your going to New Hamp.  I was calculating about sending to you by Samuel. He left here for Maine the same day your letter that came last night was written Wednesday 18th. If you were at Yarmouth he would have called there. 
I intended to send some money to you by him. It would have been a good chance for you to go to see Almeda with him. That is, if you had better go there. It seems that Almeda is not at all likely to come most any time soon: As I have written to you, She cannot come in warm weather, and James' Wife is sick and there is evidently little probability that she will be able to leave her. I judged from somewhat you wrote or said that if Almeda was not coming to Ohio this season you should want to visit her. If Samuel had called at Yarmouth while you were there you could have gone
Completed

right down to Bangor & Brownville with him. 
However it will all be right somehow, and it was unavoidable as there was no way of foreseeing the matter. Samuel I think will write you after he get to Bangor or Somewhere, and perhaps he may yet be some convenience in helping you to get there if you should think it best to try to do so. 
To go to Brownville you would have to go to Bangor on afternoon, stay over night there, and the next day have a long hard ride by Stage Coach 40 miles or more to Brownville, And at Brownville you know they live 5 miles away off over the hills and far away. Though if they knew what day to expect you they would be down to the village to meet you doubtless. 
I doubt if it is worth your while to try to go there at all this summer - at any rate - if you have to go alone. Samuel took him him that large Carpet sack well filled with things for Almeda, Large Photograph in frame, the two Bibles for James & Lizzy, and sundry dresses &c. that Anna picked out, or gave to me to pack.
I do not yet decide hardly what to do about going to Maine after you. If I should go I should not feel like stopping at all, or hardly. What time do you want to come home if I do not come after you? Perhaps you could come with Samuel when he and his wife come back which will be some time in August, he hardly knew when when here. I suppose the difficulty of coming home alone from
Completed

Yarmouth would be no more than of going there alone and much less than of going from there to New Hampshire or to Bangor. Perhaps you could get George or some one to come to Boston with you, if you chose. You say if you came to Maine, your anxiety would be only for the boys. I do not know as I should feel much anxiety about them. They are really pretty good boys. Wilder especially is in unusually good health for him. He would I think be a good boy and do well wherever he was left. Charley has not improved in health and strength this summer as Wilder has. Appetite is more irregular, is more fretful etc. etc. But he would be a good boy anywhere and Anna is exceeding good and very little trouble anywhere. And as for Little John, Eliza gets along first rate with him. And yet I do not seem to dare to leave them. Eliza does not know at all what to do with them if they are sick. If is to to be, or to be going a sickly season you know. They are all nice and well now - perhaps unusually so - but I keep thinking, 'what if they should be sick and neither of us with them.
I will send you some money in the next letter. This one will be mailed tomorrow morning before Bank hours. By the way Elyria is to be next month a Money order Post Office, which will be quite convenient. I believe there is no Bank in Yarmouth is there.
Completed

Mr Wilber preached Today, very good, rather for him odd sermon. "Let your Moderation be known to all men." Audience quite large - some out of Town, but many visitors. 
Weather here was most excessively warm from the 10th to the 18th of July, perfectly dry also. Since then a little cooler mostly cloudy and with some rain. The "heated term" surpassed almost anything previously experienced here. 

   Eliza & Wilder are gone to meeting this evening. While I stay with the Children. Eliza goes to meeting monday evenings & I Thursday. 
                   I will write again in a day or two. 
                                                 Sincerely   
                                                          Isaac
Completed

Elyria, Monday Eve
                                                                                                                       July 23d 1866

Isaac July 23
1866
Dearest
I mailed an epistle to you this morning, but it being before Bank hours, {the letter was written on Sunday}, I could not enclose my money. To day I have purchased a New York Draft for fifty dollars which I will enclose herewith. Our money order office (P.O. Money Order) will not be running till next month comes in.
This Draft will not be much trouble to you. I was almost inclined to send Bank Bills in a letter but this is safer; and if there is no Bank at Yarmouth you can easily get it cashed. Perhaps George can give you the money and, get it cashed when he goes to Portland, and give you the money, or probably any merchant or trader at Yarmouth will cash it for you. You will need to write your name across the back of the Draft, just as mine is. -- Simply your name if it goes right into Bank, Order & name (as it is now) if you want it paid to any one else.
Finish haying today - got in my meadow mowed unfortunately last Wed. the day the heated storm broke up. somewhat injured by the weather.
Eliab & Maria talk of going to Pennsylvania the same trip you & I took two years ago. Start next week, be gone some time; talk of taking two of the
Completed

children with them I think, Lucy and Willie. When do you mean to come home? All things considered, I have about come to the conclusion that I better not go after you, that is always if you think you can come alone well enough and think it best to.
If I do not you will of course stay just as long as you think best. We are getting along very well and can all summer. If you are gaining in health & strength and fat & spirits &c. &c. and May also, there where you feel the fresh salt ocean water breezes every day. You had perhaps better stay and keep doing so.
It may be for your health to stay there all through the hot weather. We can get along first rate without you - or if we should be sick or any thing the matter we could telegraph to you and you know it in an hour or two any time.
If you want more money, I can send it any time whenever you want. Let me know how much you have and write often & fully

                                                                                                                               I S Metcalf
                                                                                                                          Your
                                                                                                                               Isaac
Completed

Isaac
July 25 1866
Elyria July 25 1866
Dearest Nettie
Yours of the 20th came to hand last night and assured us of your safe arrival at Pembroke I mailed either two or three letters to you directed Pembroke, then since to Yarmouth again I did not know how long you would remain in New Hampshire. Perhaps one of them George may remail to you at Dunbarton, otherwise you may be at Dunbarton a week without any letter.
But we are all right here, whether
Completed

you hear from us or not.
I did send no pictures to you or any one by Samuel because you not being at Yarmouth when Samuel went, he would not call there.
We have got no new pictures If I do not go East to meet you, perhaps we had better let it wait. They can be sent in a letter as will after to return and get there to suit yr self as before.
Your sharp eyed conductor will chgd 1/2 fare for May, is a Conductor who puts such things on his own pocket instead of the R.R.
Completed

I should like to see Mr Willey as well as many others you have seen or will see.
I mailed a letter to Yarmouth yesterday enclosing a Draft for $50.00 payable to yr order. If you want more let me know Have all you want. Buy any thing you want that you think you can get on better terms there than here.

                                                              Absolutely yrs
                                                                            Isaac.
Completed

Isaac July 27 1866

                                                                                                                                     Elyria, July 27 1866

Very Nettie
Yours of the 23rd mailed at Concord 24th came to hand last night. Glad to hear of your well doing - expect you are enjoying a fine lot of visiting around old Dunbarton nowadays this week. Ought to have mailed a letter on time to reach you there, but did not send them to Yarmouth not knowing when or how long you would be elsewhere. Presume I should [this line covered by a fold in the paper]  enjoy visiting with you in Dunbarton some?
Some folks there I like especially well. E.G. Dea. Parker, Capt Whipple, Safford, Chas Rider.
Nothing special to communicate here. Yesterday P.M. 4 oclock, took horse & buggy & took children to ride - John & Anna & drove up to Charles' where Wilder & Charley were making hay very smartly. (Had a mowing machine at work & plenty of business for small rakers, Percy there too), took the boys in and drove around slightly. The Boys are told they shall go to the lake again after you get home. So they have an especial hurry for you to come on that Additional Cond.
Completed

Children all smart & well.
John improving daily in sleep & conduct. Meeting last eve full & strong
Rev Theodore Holmes of EA. Hartford expected to preach here next Sabbath
Dr DeWitt & Anna here a minute last eve before meeting.
Eliab & Maria out riding called also.
Twiss people at Charles yesterday P.M.
Completed

Sideways:
Isaac
July 29 1866

                                                                                                                                       Elyria, July 29, 1866

Dearest
We did not get any letter from you yesterday, and none from Dunbarton; wherefor Mrs Twiss & Mrs Bowden enquired at Church. No letter came, but Mary Barber did come arriving from Sandusky on the afternoon train However joyfully she might be welcomed, it is suspected by the cynical that a letter from yourself might have been equally welcome. Miss Barber attended a Prayer Meeting at the Baptist Church this forenoon I understand. However she was not especially missed at the Stone Church, where a quite full house was assembled to hear the Rev Theodore Holmes of East Hartford, who preached to beautiful acceptance, and also addressed the Sabbath School and also the infant class. Mr Holmes is quite a handsome young man, appearing some 10 or 15 yrs under his reputed age, rather short but quite muscular with a bright sharp blue eye. I imagine he will take well, though perhaps not very much of a preacher, but evidently an energetic live man.
Completed

Children are all finely.
Little Don John is in fine health feels better and sleeps better I think than he has since you went away. Little Anna of course frets occasionally in the very hot weather, but I think John is getting acclimated to the extreme hot weather and it agrees with him better than with Fan Anna.
The Boys, as well as Percy have worked haying up to Uncle Charles the past week some. Haying is finished now.
When are you coming home? Do not hurry yourself. We are all getting on first rate. And all probably prefer that you should stay where you are if cooler more comfortable and gaining in health & strength both of you - much as of course we should like to see you and have you at home. Charley says wont she come this week? We have done well constantly in your absence fared sumptuously every day, and I have not perceived in my self or the children any sort of lack or suffering for washing or mending. In fact I am afraid it is demonstrated that what ever we may have thought heretofore, even your precious self is not absolutely essential to the existence of the household. If you want more money I will send it any time. Next week we can have P.O. Money orders. You will want more money if you have chance to go shopping. Otherwise not perhaps.
Completed

Isaac
July 31 1866
Elyria July 31 1866
Dearest
Your letter of the 26th came to hand last night.
I am sorry about your not getting letters at Dunbarton. If I had been a little brighter might perhaps have thought better, and directed a letter or two there instead of to to Yarmouth after two to Pembroke. However perhaps George remailed one or two from Yarmouth.
I expect you are back at Yarmouth again by this time, and find a lot of letters waiting you there.
Completed

We are all in fine health and spirits. John and Anna stare about at a great rate. 
Mary Barber makes herself generally useful I judge. Washing dishes this morning while Eliza was getting to Ironing.

Eliab etc. do not go to Penn. till next week. He has got ones at work on his new fence and cannot leave them. 

Mr. Holmes goes back to Conn. Friday. Lee Twiss at our house today. 
Blackberries begin to ripen. 
Also green corn to fill.
Completed

Little Anna's Birth day the 26th. She received as gifts a slate & Pencil, a Primer, and a Picture Card from May. 
Charley's Birthday tomorrow. I presume he has anticipations, but I hardly know what or how they will be realized. 
Write frequently. 
If you want more money I will send you a P.O. money order next week. 

                                                               Sincerely, 
                                                                            Isaac.
Completed

Elyria Aug. 5 1866

Dearest

  A nice long letter from you last night from Yarmouth, written after you got back there from Dunbarton. It seems letters collected in Yarmouth to your credit while you were away in New Hampshire. I ought to have arranged so that some letters would have gone to Dunbarton. You must had had a fine time in many respects, but I am afraid you got too tired and used up.

Last Sunday you know Mr. Holmes preached here, and today, (Mr. Holmes could stop but one Sunday), Mr. Kenyon preached again. He is very much liked by many of the people; he really is a fine preacher. People will be greatly at a loss to chose between the two: Some will prefer one, and some the other, and will not know which to choose.
There is Special Church meeting called for next Friday 10th, and Special Society Meeting for Wednesday 15th.
I will go downtown myself in the Morning, and if they have got the P.O. Money Order to running I will send some to you in this letter Monday Morning. If not in another letter the next day.
Completed

I suspect you of some inclination of coming home home before long. Well I do not believe there is hardly any here who will be sorry to see you!
Though we certainly get on especially well without you. The Children are all especially - perhaps unusually well, and every thing goes on better than could have been expected.
Mary Barber you know is here now, and makes herself generally, laboriously, and universally useful -  though I do not know as every thing seems very much smoother than it did before her arrival.
Isaac
Aug. 5 1866
Completed

Isaac
Aug. 6 1866

                                                                                                 Mon. Eve Aug. 6 1866

Dearest

 I mailed a letter to you this morning. Intended to put a money order in it: but they had not got the new thing to running so they could get one off in the morning. So I sent the letter without. I have got one during the day for $20.00 only and will send that tomorrow morning. I have had it made payable to George - Rev. George A. Putnam. So he can draw it any time he goes to Portland. He will cash it for you perhaps and get it at his leisure. I do not now  as this is as much as you will want but I have got no intimation how much you do need.
Completed

I will send more any day. Have been all day today, on a crim case adjourned from all day Saturday.
The LaGrange Burglary case of last Winter of which you may remember 3 or 4 men disguised broke into Old Miss Saxton's house 2 A.M. & by threats &c. did cut her throat considerable - robbed her of $400 or 500. Finally held John Minnick, Caleb Bryant & Luther Clifford for further trial at Commun Pleas 30 or 40 Witnesses Saturday & today. Finally got through this eve. Time enough so I went in the Prayer Meeting
Rev. Mr. Kenyon there & spoke most of the evening.
Completed

Isaac Aug. 8 1866                                                                 Elyria, Aug. 8, 1866
Dearest

 I mailed a letter to you on Monday, and on Tuesday one to you and one to George, one with a Money Order for $20.00, and the other with the directions. So tomorrow morning I will mail this enclosing what I carelessly omitted to send before some of those Photographs of Don John .

Last night came to hand your letter of 3d to Wilder with a peice to myself, whereof both were glad.
Last evening, Mr. Foote of the Howard Mission whom you perhaps remember as being here last Winter was here again with six little girls from the mission to sing. Meeting
Completed

in the Pres. Church, which was quite full, almost crowded, and satisfactorily entertained by the little singers etc.
Percy reports that his father is coming the last of next week.
Shall you come with him?
If we had no other reason, I do not know but we should begin to get anxious to have you come, for the very press of enquiry for you. I begin to think you are the most important personage in this part of town; or in your whole circle of relatives & friends. Mrs. Gates is sick in Cleveland. Father Monteith made a formal call here yesterday.
Completed

It is reported today that Rev. John Monteith has asked a dismission from Euclid St. Cleveland.
Mrs. Rollin DeWitt does not come home yet on account of the severe illness of her father.
Mr. S. L. Nelson is east.
The Combat between Washburn & Doolittle for Probate Judgeship deepens.
Miss Mary Barber is very industrious throughout the house, and appears to be a very active and efficient assistant generally to Eliza; but I do not know but we get along just as smoothly and well as we have any time. The Children are all well and good natured, and we are generally
Completed

generally highly comfortable and convenient.
Abundance of Green corn, and most all kinds of vegetables, besides the Blackberries, of which Eliza Canned the first I think today.
If this or any other letter should not reach Yarmouth till after you start for home, it can fall gracefully to the rest.
There will be nothing serious or substantial enough to hurt them.
Love & kisses from several of us to Little Mary as well as yrself.

                                                              Sincerely,
                                                                           Isaac
Completed

Elyria Aug. 10 '66

Very Dearest Nettie

   I do not know but I have sent letters enough to you this week. And I did not get any from you today. But perhaps I could write a thing or two. You need not trouble yourself even to think of calling at Hartford to see Hattie Gaylord. She is expected here within a few days, perhaps tomorrow. Her husband has decided to leave where he now is, probably got West again somewhere. And from Mrs. G's peculiar condition, it is essential that if she moves at all she should do it at once , So She is coming here at once to remain etc.

This will render it necessary for Percy to go somewhere else to board.
Enough of that - You need not go to Hartford

A letter for you came today from C. Thurston, which I will not send to you as perhaps you may leave Yarmouth before it would reach you. I have opened and read the letter and will give you the substance of the contents.
Completed

Written from Dryden N.Y. Aug. 6th. At the request Sister who is unable to write herself.
Soon after writing you She had another and more severe Billious Attack, her lungs also are diseased, her throat sore - unable to speak aloud, very much emaciated, sits up but little; cannot remain many months. Hope to get her home in a few weeks, which however will not be easy unless she can gain a little more strength as there are ten miles of carriage ride. If you have not returned to Elyria they think you will take their place on yr way.
(This I do not think you could do now expecting to find them at home, for it is very doubtful I judge if she ever gets home)
Mary ( the letter continues) is desirous to see you and would have sent a letter to you before this if she could, but entirely unable to write herself and Mother too feeble to write much. Mother has been with her five weeks. etc. (I do not know where Dryden is, and presume you would not be likely to see any of the family except by going there  -  at present,
Church Meeting this Afternoon.
Expressions of Opinion as to the Ministers by ballot  Holmes 33

                                                                               Kenyon 18} some blanks, greatly to the surprise of many who thought it was to be almost all the
Completed

other way. And I do not know but it might have been, if it had not been for the circumstances and way it was done.
Dr. DeWitt had made a very effective speech against hasty action  - the necessity of knowing more about any Minister before we gave him a call. (You know this Church once settled a Pastor, who withing a year or two was deposed from the Ministry for stealing his sermons). Thereupon Mr. Gates and I.S. Metcalf, appeared to know every thing and told every thing of & about Mr. Holmes; and no one could do the same or really knows much any thing about Mr. Kenyon,
Then his coming from Princeton Old School is against him especially Congregationally. But he certainly is a splendid preacher. Doubtless much superior to Mr. Holmes in that respect at least.
Thereupon 33 to 18, It was apparently unanimously Noted to request the Society to unite in requesting Mr. Holmes to come and preach as Stated. Supply for one year with a view to settlement eventually as Pastor.
Society Meeting next week.
Combat thickens quo ad Probate Judge Ship.
Considerable excitement about the renomination
Completed

of Common Pleas Judge Burks thereof the Convention is next week The last month before Lorain Co. Fair is passing, wherein the Secretary is a busy individual.
Excuse this ridiculously blotted sheet.
Love etc,

                                Exceedingly
                                                     Isaac

[lower right side]  Isaac

                      Aug. 10 1866
Completed

Isaac Aug 12 1866

                                                                                                                          Elyria, Aug. 12, 1866

Dearest

 Your letter of the 8th came to hand last evening. I think I wrote four or five to you last week.

Now I am a little at a loss whether this will reach you before you start to leave Yarmouth for Ohio for we are somewhat expecting you to come home when Samuel Furber comes. and I understand he has written to Percy to expect him the latter part of this week.
If that should be so, you & Samuel come together this week, you will probably start before this gets to Yarmouth. But if you should not come this week, you might like another letter. We are all in good health & spirits.
I wrote you a day or two since that you need not go to Hartford as Hattie DeWitt Gaylord was expected here daily. I guess they expected her last night but she did not come I think. I sent you last week a P.O. Money order for $20.00, and two or three Photographs of John.
Completed

Mr. Wilbur preached this morning from "The Peace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you" Closing with very fervent invocations of blessing and peace, there were many tearful faces among his Audience.  It is said to be doubtful whether he preaches here again. I think expects to go to Wabash, Indiana, where he preached last Sabbath. It is said his family will remain here awhile at least.
Collection taken up today for A.B.C.F.M. Rather out of place, belonged in February but crowded out then, and necessary now as the last opportunity almost to get it in before the historical year of Am. Board closes this month.
Our new S.S. Library used today for the first time. Not a great attendance on account of a rainy day.
This Eve there was to have been a Tract Society Meeting addressed by Dr. McIlvane. I do not know whether there was any meeting or not. Just at Meeting time came of very violent shower, with extreme Thunder & lightning. Charles & Albina came in & after the Shower went home without going to Meeting. Neighbour Chandler & Wife took shelter here from the violence of the show a while.
Completed

I am getting quite busy at my office now adays. The Ag. Fair is coming along, which is just about a Months' work for me. The Boys have been helping me at Office considerably the past week. Wilder is quite quick and good at help about various thing, arranging class & Premium Cards etc. Then you know I have been editing a new Edition of the Union School Regulations etc. which I have entirely rewritten.
The our new S.S. Library, I have written in and Catalogued. Getting up a new Catalogue to be printed etc. All these matters, with an occasional day of Justice Court, (two days on one case lately) with Church and Minister matters, and an exciting political canvass just coming on you may imagine draw one to my office a good many forenoons as well as the appointed 2 to 4 P.M.
You talk of rosy cheeks for Little May. Tell her I challenge her to bring home some to compare with Little Don John.

 Well it is getting to be bed time. Best love frm me to George & Fanny. Tell May she may kiss little George Herbert three times for me, (That is if he likes to be kissed)  Ask Father to write me.                               Unconditionally
                                                                                                          Isaac.
Completed

Why do you not
write more particularly
about your own health?
Completed

Elyria Aug 14 1866

Isaac
Aug 14 1866

                          Dearest
                                 Letter from you last night, yours of the 9th Inst. But I did not write to you having Mailed one to you that morning. Percy got a letter from his Father last Night saying he might be expect next Week Wednesday or thereabouts.

Hattie Gaylord arrived tonight in good apparent health as I understood.
But Anna has no girl at all and is in great need of one. 
Tomorrow I told of going to Medina to Judicial Convention to renominate Judge Burke. If you were at home I should have to go on the day after to Congressional Convention to renominate Judge Welker for Congress That I escape on the plea of yr absence
Completed

Mr. Wilbur - I told you of his farewell sermon on Sunday. He is going right away this week. Take charge of a Female College at Wabash Indiana.
His family stay here awhile.
Funeral Services of Rev. Mr. Grosvener tomorrow. I wrote you I think how he died of Cholera at Cincinnati last week did I not.
Charles & Jos. Rich at work here this week with Team. Charles also tomorrow. Our folks all very well.
Very good sort of Children also.
Some of them think that they will be glad to see their Mother.
Mary Barber goes tomorrow to Rochester or Cambden or some where South End of Country to some Baptist Conventicle or other.

                                   Assuredly
                                                  Isaac.
Completed

[right-hand side] I S. Metcalf Topsham 
Nov. 29, 46

                                                                               Topsham, Nov. 29th, 1846

Dear Brother Eliab,

   I received with much pleasure your letter of the 21st inst. a few days since.
 It really did me good : I had almost forgotten how your writing looked, it had been so long since I had received any of your writing.
 As regards your complaints about my letters, I acknowledge their justice to the full; at least as far as my lack is concerned: It was just exactly no letter at all, and I did not really send it as one. I thought I wrote the circumstances; I was intending to write some letters to send with a book by a friend. The fellow started a week sooner than I expected. I was as I now constantly am much pressed with a variety of occupations. However, I 'hooked' most an hour in the morning from recitation & breakfast, most another at noon, and wrote four whole letters of which the one you received was a fair sample!
  I hardly considered them all worth a single letter postage, in fact they hardly cost it; but I wanted just to put some of you in mind that there was such a brother of you as "I.S."
 As I said I was much gratified at receiving your letter; although, instead of answering my multitude of questions, you seem to have preferred, with some justice to be sure, to retort them upon myself: and now I suppose I must fain try my own hand at answering some of them.
Completed

So it seems that Almeda has really got started to spend the winter in Mass. Do you know where she is going to be? Is she going to Royalston & Warwick, or among the Searles? or is she going all round the lot?
And little Jamie stays behind. I wonder if the little fellow was contented to be left. By the way I judge that he is rather a good little boy, is he not?
Where should I direct a letter to Almeda? She ought to write to me.  Will it not be considerable trouble to Charles to take care of her things? tend "critters" in both barns, I suppose, must he not?
It will take all his time this winter to 'do the chores', without any teaming; that is, if he has no boy.
Most I am afraid of is that he will not get time to be married! What think you of it!

  What induced Mr. Brown & Son to move across the stream? I should think it inconvenient to be so far off. I believe W. Brown owns his dwelling, so he will not move that. I guess you will move back next year. Do you have to go away over there to open the store all these cold mornings, and back again before breakfast? or do you get yr breakfast first? I would, I think.
 I should not think Your Brown's house was not big enough for so large a party as 420 invitations. guess it was lucky it was a rainy evening. I was at a much bigger one in a biggest house 'tother night.'
 The same rainy Thursday night, did n't I have a great ride home in the rain from somewhere? Eh!
Completed

Dec.  3d. Thanksgiving. It seems to me I could have been 'summut' more thankful to day, if I could have got some letters from "Down East". It is about a month since I have heard any thing from Milo. I have toiled through this pouring rain & awful wet footing to both Post Offices. & got ______
Androscoggin Bank, Topsham. paid me yesterday $90.-- in part for teaching village school. Of which sum however I owe to various persons in Brunswick & Topsham & to Bowd. Coll. somewhat more than $150,00 I guess.
They do not all get their pay this hitch, do they! especially as I intend to reserve some $20,00 or 30,00 of it at least to pay my expenses in a contemplated trip to Yale, New Haven. I rather expect now to make a week's vacation, & go to Yale Col. a few days, probably about Christmas. The Expenses of Journey however may be mostly refunded to me. Even if it does cost my own purse something, it may be no great loss to me in the end. It may not hurt me.

  As for my situation here, I suppose you know pretty well about. I teach Topsham Village "Upper School." Considerable of a school, but a very laborious one abundance of bad scholars; some flogging, some scolding, some "getting along." It is a difficult affair. Some of them are ripening off rather fast. I fear they will go to seed at Thomaston? yet.

However, I get along - "comfortably". I guess give good satisfaction. At any rate all the "Chief Priests and Rulers" are on my side & influence.

 I have got considerably introduced to the Society of Topsham like it much. plenty of pleasant people. takes my time though
Completed

4th I undertook to finish this letter yesterday P.M. but Josephine made me play Chequers, and then some College friends came over,and so took my time that I had to put it off till Evening.
With Evening came a pressing invitation to the annual select game of "Blind Man's Buff" in the kitchen of the Rev. Mr. Wheeler, Unitarian Clergyman of Topsham. My little brother 'Charley', son of said Clergyman , was imperative. Very pleasant little company, only dozen 16 or so, children & all. Regular old fashioned good time. good for the blues, or a homesick fellow.

 You retort my question "What are you reading?" It is not so easy a question for me to answer as for you. I read a great deal of every thing, perhaps too much. (no newspapers though), With Libraries of 20,000 & more Volumes at command, Every late work and all the important periodicals, review etc. American & Foreign.  Of course I do not look for matter of reading. When one is teaching so laboriously, one cannot well read, that is study, much real scientific or deep works. It is troublesome to 'think' too much besides teaching such a school & studying one recitation per day, as I do. However I must to keep up my literary staning read a good deal.  All the new things, reviews etc. Perhaps it makes too much reading for the thinking, induces a kind of mental Plethora. I guess you will think as much of this letter without it were better.

Some of "the gals" are coming this evening to play 'goose'  I must dress a least bit If you will write soon I will try and do better next time. Excuse this
Your Brother I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Northfield, April 21st. 1848

Dear Brother Eliab

   How happens it that I do not hear from you oftener? Now I remembered in a letter I received from you last Winter, there was I suppose intended an answer to this question. However perhaps the letter itself was its own best refutation, for certainly he who can write such letters as that, ought to write far more of them than you do.
 I had a letter from Anne a few days since, but it is now a good while since I have heard from either you or Joseph. I am thinking every day about you both, and am anxious to hear how you are getting on, and what business prospects are with you for the coming season. I suppose it has been rather dull times through the winter; and probably it will hardly be such a season for business as the last was, either in Bangor, or anywhere else. Business depression always follows near; and the results even of the Mexican War will undoubtedly have great effect, even in parts so remote from the principal scene of action. In a pecuniary point of view merely, War may be compared to a sort of National "Spree", perhaps borrowing money to go off gambling, or to a horse race; The depression which follows with peace is the going to work again to pay up the debts incurred. There ~ what think of that comparison?  Seriously however, this war appears to me a dreadful thing. ~ not so much in its immediate or pecuniary effects. those cannot materially affect a Nation like U.S. but in its moral & political effects upon this Nation as well as
Completed

upon the Continent and the world. Engaging, under whatever pretext, in a War of Conquest, seems such an outrageous departure from the whole spirit and tendency of our institutions, and one likely to be productive of such dreadful results.
And then too the spirit and feeling it engenders and which seems to be so much developing itself through the country, a spirit which until lately we had fondly hoped our country was too wise ever to give way too, a spirit & feeling which have been the destruction of all, especially of Republican Governments. 
It almost makes me sick to hear men talk of the destiny of the U.S. and the Anglo Saxon race; to spread over the whole continent etc. and to think that people are imbibing such sentiments the very sentiments which destroyed Republican Greece, and Republican Rome; which so dreadfully destroyed the Republican France of the last Century. Oh that the Country, with its beginning, its advancement, and its destiny which seemed opening before it; upon which it seemed to be so fairly entering. Its field of glory & ambition might have been so different, so new, so grand. It did seem destined to surpass all predecessors: but how? In the Old blood stained darkened path in which the Nations of the Earth have trod, and by the sides of which their mouldering bones lie bleaching, it could not hope to exceed, or to gain new glory. The days of Cannae & Phillippi, of Austerlitz & Bodorino, we hope are passed. But there is a nobler destiny, a field of higher glory, an ambition to render our country the light & the blessing of the Nations, the foremost of the new grand advance of peace, liberty, and religion.

 But while our own beloved and favored land seems thus going backwards, receding from its high advance ground; the mighty events now going
Completed

on in Europe. are irresistably claiming the Attention & interest of all. I am interested in watching the present Revolutions in Europe as the development in great measure of a new principle, as the type of a New Era in European history. They are the outbreak of labor, instead of Money. Formerly in Europe as every where, the Warrior held sway, the sword ruled with the kind & the baron who weilded the sword. In former revolutions Money asserted its power; the Merchant the citizen rose up against the Baron, the peer: the purse claimed precedence power with or above the sword.
It was somewhat so even in the Revolution of this country; varied true by the peculiar character & influences of the people. Ye Monet was the Case. France illustrates the point. In former revolutions, in 1790 or 1830, it was the "Bourgeois", the citizen, the man of property, who rebelled and cast down the government, the government of the sword.
In February, in Paris, as it has been in Germany & Italy; it was an other, a lower which lifted up the head: one ho was hardly thought worthy of Notice before. This is the revolution of the "the Man in the blouse." of the laborer, rather than of the Bourgeoise.   Before it was only the Merchant threw the Money bag into the seale against the sword and weighed it down. The Man in the blouse perhaps fared little better under the Merchant, than under the Baron.  But here, as I read if saw a real incident in one of the German States, the Blouse man himself, before only the instrument of others. a big blacksmith stretched out his bony arm and laid his calling hand upon the shoulder of the Prince, demanding, & obtaining too, a Constitution!  I suppose you read in the papers at least enough to know something of the Astonishing events going forward in Europe.  Do you also read U.S. politics. What appear to be prevailing ideas of the coming presidential affairs? Are you interested in these things? And what Candidate for the Presidency do you prefer. 
[left-hand side]The Blouse is the frock of the European peasant.
Completed

My friend Morse writes to me that one of the Topsham girls has been passing the Winter in Bangor, Miss Caroline Walker is being plentifully courted by a Mr. Gould, a Lumberman, is it your Gould, who has so much to do at Brown's? 
Is Edwin at home? and how does he carry himself?
How do you and Frank agree nowadays? I believe you enter upon a new year at Brown's this Month. Upon what sort of terms do you continue there? You ought to write to me of all these things, and very many others. Among others of how Charles Harlow is doing, or is like to do.

 You know I am coming up on to Bangor soon. Am expecting now to start within a fortnight. I have written perhaps to Joseph about sending me a paper to know about the Boats.

Will not you see to it. I think I shall go by R.R. to Portland, then by Steamboat, and want to know what days, and on arrival of what trains. They say there is to be a great time up to Milo. We shall see. 
This letter is not worth sending hardly. I do not know but I might have thought of something to write about my self or my business, but I shall soon be there and can tell all.

                                                                    I enclose letter to Joseph & Anne
Completed

Isaac
                                                                           Somewhere in Jackson Co. Ill.  Sabbath Day
                                                                                                        July 6. 1851

Dear Brother Eliab.

      This letter, if letter it becomes, will be addressed to you probably; but its contents must be considered as addressed to yourself, Mother, Lucy etc. individually & collectively.
 I wish you could be here about half a day. You know the old saw that "This is a great world." Well, in some respects, this here is rather a great part of the world. Northern Illinois is called by Eastern people mostly, Southern by a sprinkling of every thing, mostly south of New York. Where I am boarding Penn. Dutch. Very many are from Tenn. & Ky. Take them together, a very curious set of people. A mile apart in the closest neighborhood a known, (I expect forms a Village! Every one farms an immense amount of land, and pastures the whole surrounding country.

Where we are now, eight or ten miles across Muddy River Valley is Timber. Farms are about as plenty in the Timber as any where but I guess such a thing as felling a tree was never known here. The trees are girdled, and stand or fall till they rot. A farm is a forest of dead trees. The Crops raised are {Wheat. $.50 per bu.
{Corn      .25 "     "
{Oats      .25  '    "
{Castor Beans  .50  " " sometimes $1.00 or more
Both Tobacco & Cotton are also raised some. Peaches are the principal fruit, but this year unfortunately for me they were killed by frost.

 Yesterday I worked through a Corn field where the Corn stood 8 to 10 ft. high, just ready to topel. Ears are sometimes found 10 ft from the ground. I presume though it yeilds no more than smaller corn. One or two ears in a hill, 3 or four ft. apart both ways, no hoeing, plough and cross plough through it several times.
Completed

My first work here commenced upon Muddy River, in a little Cane Brake, at a Sweet Gum Tree; thence to a Post Oak Tree. I hardly know as there are any trees here which are found down in Maine. Some of the Massachusetts Trees. Hickory or Walnut, many different kinds of which are abundant here. White Oak is rare here. The great bulk of the Timber {All Woodland is called Timber here} is Post Oak, with some Pin Oak, and Black Oak, abundant Hickory, some Gum, Persimmon etc. Cotton Wood, Sycamore & that clan in the River Bottoms.  Beside there are much Locust, and some Plum trees etc. wild in the woods.
Plants & Flowers are various and abundant.
There is no such thing known as any of the Pine or Fir family, no black growth. All hard wood every where.
The houses are Log, hewn or unhewn, and built in a fashion to make a Yankee stare. Poor folks have one room only. no matter if 20 in family. Those better off, that is those whose farms all worth say more than $5000.00 have 2 rooms, never more.
They are all built alike the 2 rooms are 2 houses just alike, 8 to or 12 feet apart, with one roof extending over both and the intermediate space, which in other respects is all open, This called "the Porch, is the principal place where the people live always eat & sit there. And really at this season at least, they are certainly the most comfortable places I ever found under a roof. Always a current of air through.
Where I now board, at a house of this kind, 2 large rooms & Porch, very good specimen of the class; wealthy Dutch Farmer, family of 12 to 20. Our Party makes an addition of 10 or 12. All very well accommodated! The family, you remember, includes a number of strapping girls too.

 Probably there is no one of these one of these one room houses, no matter how large the family, where they would not be ready and willing to hospitably accommodate strangers or travellers.
Completed

Well there is little or nothing in this letter and it is but little since I wrote last to some of you. But Postage is reformed now and amounts to scarcely a little. I am off a good ways, a long way; (right smart of distance; the suckers would say) from the rest of you. I want to gear from you often, and I am willing to take it for granted that some of you will be willing to hear from me, and I shall write perhaps every sabbath if I get time.
Completed

some of the expressions of the people here would amuse you. "like" for "as" eg. I do like I do}'.  "allow" for think, guess etc. etc.
"I reckon" is the universal answer instead of yes or any Affirmatipn. One with ague is "powerful weak" The farmer raises "right smart" of corn," and has "heap" of cows or horses. "Pack" for carry. etc. But their ways are far more curious than their words.
I believe I can stop to write no more.
Sincerely

                  I.S.
Completed

Mt. Hawkins, Perry Co. Illinois
                     Sabbath, August 3, 1851

Dear Brother Eliab

   It is very many letters that I have addressed to you since I last saw you, and since I have heard a word from you in any form or manner; I do not know but it is a dozen in twenty.  At any rate it is about one a week for the whole time, and that seems to me, judging by my own feelings must be two or three years at the least.

This present letter is not so much written because I have any thing special as of importance to write unto you just now. Nor simply because the Postage is low. But simply principally, merely; or in great part to call your attention renewedly to the heading of this page, as a phrase extremely suitable to be used by you a part of the superscription of sundry letters. I really believe it would look remarkally well upon the lower right hand corner of letters post marked Bangor Maine
Completed

If you judge that the preceeding page was written in the dark, you will judge not far amiss.
We have been the last week in Office here at the Residence of B.G. Roots Esq. commonly known as Locust Hill. and which was formerly a large Boarding School kept by said B.G. Roots, who is now however connected with the R.R.

 By the way I must tell you while I think of it.  You know when I came on here, I would not agree to remain any time at all: only said I would come out and go to work, receive $2.50 per diem, and leave when I chose.
Well, at the end of July, I find, myself allowed $3.00 per diem for the whole time.

Moreover I see my name set down from August First, at $3.50 per diem.

 It looks a little as if they wanted to keep me here, does it not?

I presume that if I stay I can do well here, if the climate agrees with me.
Mr. Roots is an Episcopalian, what they call a Lay Reader. and has regular service in full form at his house every Sabbath. That is the only Meeting however in the region, perhaps within 10 or 12 miles. May be some Methodist School House perhaps.
Completed

You can hardly imagine how anxious I am to hear from you all. Here I have written to Bangor about once a week since June 25. I have already received answers to letters written to New England almost a fortnight later but have as yet seen not one word from Maine.
I believe I write to you all in about every letter that the name of County, "Perry Co" was the most important part of address. I cannot see what is the matter/
It is possible Eliab is not in Bangor, Perhaps has followed my advice, and journeyed to New York State.
But in that Case you would get his letters and answer  At any rate I shall not direct this letter to him.  Failing to get any answer from Mother at Bangor, I have just written to her at Milo. This Letter Lucy you may consider as written to you specially & Samuel to whom I will direct it. and shall expect you both to answer it immediately.

 My health is very good, strength ditto. The warm weather they say is over mostly for this year. If not I have acquired the power of bearing it better. My only trouble now is to hear from you. And tomorrow I must got off 20 or 30 mls. and the letter of tomorrow's mail will not reach me for two or three days.
 Well there is nothing in this letter, but I will send it as only 3 cts worth out of Spite and Love to You All
                                                                                                                                                       I.S.
Completed

Isaac Aug. 1851

Mt. Hawkins Ills.}                                                                                  Paid 3
Aug. 4th}                                              Samuel W. Furber

                                 Paid I.S.M.                Bangor
                                                                               Maine
Completed

Perry Co. Illinois Aug. 15. 1851
                                                                                                                                "       17. 1851

Dear Brother Eliab

   Your letter of July 29. 1851 dated at Woonsocket R.I. reached me nearly two days ago.

I wanted very much to dispatch a letter at once to Westfield, hoping it might meet you there; but it was almost impossible. I should not have minded stopping the Party while I wrote it, but the expense of sending a man off to Post Office express 8 or 10 miles with it would have been perhaps $2. or 3.00 and add to this the extreme probability that if it arrived at the P.O. that evening it would get started before tomorrow morning. In short, it was best to wait.
You expected a letter from me at Woonsocket. Well, you do not yet realize how far out of the world I am, nor the difficulties in the was of the rapid transmission of intelligence to certain portions of our Country. I did not receive your letter requesting me to write to Woonsocket until Aug. 9. 1851, more than a week as you perceive after you left Woonsocket. If I had written immediately to Woonsocket, it would probably have arrived there sometime early in September. Again you will perceive { if you ever have a chance} the great impossibility of your ever receiving this letter in Westfield. So it will probably reach there sometime in September.

  The first letter I received from Maine, the first I heard from there after I left there in May last, was I think Aug. 6 or 7, when I received one from you, enclosing one from Alabama, and merely stating that you had all written week or two before. Moreover that you hoped Lucy was a little better than she had been. Well I did not know whether to think she was very sick or not. But two or three days after came other letters written a week or two before, and I have got one written by Lucy just after you left Bangor.

You can hardly imagine how much better I have felt since. I believe I have written to Anne twice since I came here, but have not yet received any thing from there.
To Bangor or Milo I have written or intended I intend to write about every week.
Completed

Moss E. A. Rich

I am glad you are travelling about.
I wish I could travel with you.
It is much more pleasant travelling in company
As comparatively an "Old Traveller" I could undoubtedly be of considerable service to you. The "Art of travelling" is certainly quite an art, to travel easily, comfortably, to enjoy it.
Still I expect Directions are not easily given. We must learn by experience, easier by experience in company with 'one who knows' to be sure.
If I had been with you when you started I would have given you a Chapter of directions.
I have no time now
The man leaves for the P.O. now.
I want to see you much, but cannot expect you to come here, could not advise you if you want to get back this Season.
Look in N.Y. Go to Chicago if you have time. Look where in Lumber business.

                                       Aff.  I S.

I shall direct this to Mass.
Completed

Dunbarton, N.H.
                                                                                                                               Sept. 6 1856

Dear Eliab

              The hand of the Lord is heavy upon me.

Mayo is dead. Our joy, our pride, our strength, our first born.
He was sick when I got back from Bangor, Saturday night or rather Sunday morning. It was a malignant dysentery, and nothing seemed to do any thing to help it. He grew worse & worse sunk rapidly, until this morning at 3:45, when I closed those eyes I do loved, after watching the last quiver of agony in that little frame. Oh, it is a hard thing to bear to see such a little one suffer so.
Completed

It is a dreadful disease!
How he has suffered! And just as patient as a lamb all the time.
Oh, Eliab pray for us that all these things may be sanctified to our good. I expect I worshipped the the gift rather than the Giver, and now He has taken it away.
I cannot write more

                  Isaac
Completed

Ducoign, Perry Co. Illinois
                                                                                              Wed. Eve. Jan. 28th, 1857

Dear Brother Eliab

  By mail this afternoon came to hand your kind letter of Jan. 15th; also one from Samuel of Jan. 16 or 17th. For both of them I am heartily obliged to the respective writings. I was very glad to get these letters, but no more so than two others which arrive at the same time from Elyria.

I have by no means decided to go into the Ill. Central R.R.Co. Employ as Coal Manager. Probably shall determine to have nothing to do with it. Not however from the reason you suggest - that the $1500.00 per Annum is small pay. It is rather large pay for the office; larger than $2000.00 as a R.R. Engineer, or Superintendent; probably about equal to $2500.00 There is quite a difference. The Engineer or Superintendent belongs to the R.R. Co. not exactly ~ "body & Soul"; but day & night, waking or sleeping, his whole existence is in a measure merged in that of the R.R. he seems to have no separate life, feeling, or interest.
The Coal Manager, on the other hand, has got no Rail Road, with its interests & responsibilities of life & property
Completed

attached to him, he would be no more than the Manager for any other Corporation or business. And then it ought to be worth at least one thousand dollars a year to my property and interests here to have me here all the time, and not too confined to be able to attend somewhat to my own interests. This Property is becoming more and more valuable, and more and more needs the owner's looking after.
There is now more than six seven thousand dollars dollars due on account of sale of lots here. The sales are now about two thousand dollars per month. Soon there will be another form of receipts from Coal rents and leases, and all needs looking after by the proprietor. If the proprietor, or either, or any proprietor is constantly absent his interests must and will suffer.
However, I do not think I shall stay here. Neither do I regard the Climate as a great objection. There is certainly no lovelier climate than this for the larger part of the year. And it is getting very easy now to go North with ones family in the summer months; very much easier than it was when I first came to this country; When one could not get away at all at some seasons of the year.
What is, or is to be the Name & Style of your
Completed

your firm now Samuel goes out of it?
How do you expect to get along alone?
Be careful and not wear yourself out before your time. Try to take life easy. Hope to hear that your baby is entirely well and healthy. I think you Bangor people keep Children in the house too much. They should be warmly wrapped as not to feel the cold, but should get the out door air often. I think now it may be best to get Charles out here again somewhere. He could do well here now as a carpenter at any rate. Carpenter's wages here now are $2.00 to $2.50 per day, and likely to be higher rather than lower. And really Charles is better than the Average of Carpenters in this County. But perhaps I will have some good place on R.R. business this spring. I have had one or two situations offered me already; but none that I want exactly. And I cannot yet tell what I shall do.
Do you not think you had better give up at Bangor and come West some where. A little money goes farther here than East. It does not take a great deal to live on where Money is worth 20 to 25 per cent.
I wish Samuel would conclude to
Completed

to leave Percy at Elyria, while he goes to Minnesota. Will Mother really not come out with him?
I do not pay very special attention to politics, since the Presdtl Elections.

I wrote a long letter to Mother only a few days ago.

Write me if you make $30,000.00 by raising that sunken Ship.
Is there any thing of interest in Bangor this Winter? How are the times about money? Are there various failures?
I wish you would write frequently

                        Sincerely
                                      Isaac S.
Completed

Elyria Ind. May 29 '57

Dear Brother

          Think I wrote you not long since, and since receiving any thing from you. Have however seen some business notes from you to the Doctor about Evergreens. By the way  the man - Newberry man, - for whom those trees were ordered was somewhat inclined not to take them - thought they might be only the common Fir that grows here, said they looked as if they were only dug up in the woods, instead of raised in a nursery - probably would not lose many of the, - Firs out of the woods never did etc. The Doctor will probably write you about it. The Box did not arrive till yesterday I believe.

I bought a house yesterday. That is bargained for it, and made out the papers- but am not to take possession till the first of October next.
Completed

It is on West Avenue, about as far from Judge DeWitt's, as where we now live, but more out of town. 4 1/2 Acres of Land back end of the lot a fine grove on there. West Branch river bank, over two hundred young, fruit trees of choice varieties started on it - story & half house, small not large enough for our family.
Shall add a little to the side of the house just to increase the size of our bedroom, just as your house was fixed.
I pay $2100.00 for the place. The Doctor says it is worth $3000.00 I do not know but I may have to draw upon you to make the first payment in a few days. I have an abundance due from DuQuoin, but collecting come rather slow from there. If I draw upon you how will it inconvenience you? It would suit you very well I suppose if I should draw on you for $500. or 500.00 on 60 days, and get it discounted here, and then send you a New York Draft for the same Amount within 30 days. 
How are your finances this Summer. I wish you would write to me.
Completed

more frequently & particularly. Please write on receipt of this.

 We had a letter from Samuel this week - all well- Theodore sick.
 The Legislature there just in session have distributed the Congregational land grand. The Minnesota & Pacific R.R. Co. which get the great East and West line - The fifty corporations - Minnesota Men - are Directors for the first year. P.P. Furber & Sam'l Stanchfield are prominent. Surveys to be commissioned immediately. S.W. thinks I.S. Metcalf can be Chief Engineer. I was almost inclined to start right up there next week.

Judge DeWitt has been quite sick confined to his house for two weeks or more, just got about again. 
Anna is pretty well.
Antoinette quite "
Baby         very "
And all the rest of us also. 
Please send immediately

                         Sincerely 
                                       I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Chandler. Clement, Wing & 2 Sinclairs study Surveying. Start Classes Algebra

                                                                                                                   Foxcroft, May 30th, 1844

Dear Brother

                            I received a letter from Milo, last Sat, The 25th, in which was written that you had been 'heard from'. I had learned about as much near a week before. Tash saw Butters & heard from you! although B.- did not know what you were doing.
Lucy wrote only that you were at work in a Lath Mill at Oldtown, for $11, per month.

I can only advise you to be careful of yourself & be sure that you get your wages. You cannot afford to ' take much 'out of bones, for 10,00 per month. Though I dont know but that is about as much as you could expect to get, in cash, and work no harder than other people do, on a farm, for instance.

 I am pretty comfortably situated here, board at Mr Sewall Cochrane's, a very good place, Wm. P. Wing is my Roommate, a very fine fellow. School began Mond. the 20th, with 15 scholars, Tues. 21, Wed. 26. This week 30 and upwards.  Pretty good school. Philbrick, Blake, Owens, Washburn, Cake, Clement, Chandler, Wing, Stevens of Sangerville, Trafton, 2 Sinclairs of S. Dover good scholars etc. etc. Miss Foss, Tash, C. Holmes, Hopkins, Chandler, Palmer, Simpson, Farnham, M. Edes & 5 or 6 little girls.  Botanical Excursions bid fair to be quite an object this summer. I found, the other day, a flower I saw once last summer on the bog, but could not carry home. I expect it to be Orchis Spectabilis! curious looking plant, small,
Completed

I expect I shall be 'head botanist,' this summer! though I do not know much about analyzing plants, still my knowledge is of a more practical character than any of the rest of the folks. Mr. Tash knows nothing about plants not even the names of any plants, common or classical. Miss Foss pretends to be something of a botanist & has a herbarium but I guess her science is somewhat of the J. Prentiss order. 
Prentiss has gone to Paris or somewhere. Others are rusticating, or at least, farming. Girls all School marms.

 I had a long letter from Gilman Clark last week You have probably heard of the great Row there lately.
 They read 1/2 or 2 pages of Xenophon there per diem & 2 of Livy. I generally read from 3 to 7 pages of Xenophon every morning before school & 3 or 4 or more pages of Livy in this course of the day. Smyths Algebra is not slow!
 B.E. Clement rooms with Mr. Tash at Moultons, where Lucy would not let me. C. Holmes with Miss Tash at Stevens, Oakes & Stevens at Douty's.  Still times!
 The 'Logs' have got down. Started by the last 4 days rain, arrived here Wed. Dams, ponds, rivers, & booms all full of them. Sort them all over in Gilmans boom Strickland turned over for Oldtown. Considerable part of them however are piled up on the 2 dams, opposite my window.  S.A. Moulton is to be married in a few weeks to J.W. Kelsey of Port Huron, Michigan 
  Wed. P.M. Went in swimming. W.P. Wing got in deep water and came near drowning. I picked him out without difficulty. He dont feel just well since!
Completed

[left-hand side] Careful of your health & constitution Also your mind & your heart.
I suppose things are going on in about the old style at home. Walton was there and put up a Chimney Friday before I left. I dont know whether Gilman is there this week or not. Their farming is either late for the season.
Ezra Barker was here last week is going to have his lame leg amputated, & wished to be Mesmerized, but he has naturally such a constitution that Dennis could not come it over him. He has been 3 years at Philips Exeter Academy, go up to top. Took 2 or 3, hundred dollar prizes, in succession. Supported by prize money etc. entirely, 3 years, without teaching or anything.

 His Class, in which his bill was No. 1, all entered Cambridge last fall, a year in advance. Enquire how he succeeded last winter, 8 month, with that great school of 100+ Oldtown rowdies; cripple as he is, had hardly stood up since. 

It is too bad for such a fellow as he is, or might be, to lose a leg, mutitate such a peice of timber.

 Philips Exeter, by his report, must be a place for Severe discipline, thorough scholarship, & great advantages. 3 teachers No. of students limited to 72. Charity students, preferred, smart ones. Richly funded, Thousand dollars dont know but more, distributed in prizes, per annum. Large libraries, every thing right.

Had not you or Eliab better try to go there. Barker says there is no difficulty in admittance in Charity, for one good scholar etc. Almost advised me to go there. Old & advanced as I am. by him discipline is about equal to a College course, common.
I dont know but the Abstract of News which with I have fits this paper will be interesting to you or not. I will try & do better again, both matter & manner Ever I.S. Metcalf
Completed

May 20  1844
Isaac.
Foxcroft
June 15              Mr. Joseph M. Metcalf                            10

                                                     Oldtown
                                                              Maine

Sat. June 1st Eve. I have just returned from an Excursion, ride. J. Chandler has a brother lives up in Shirley. He was going up & invited me to take a seat in his waggon yesterday. It began to rain, but we did not get wet having a large umbrella. Stopped at Monson 3 or 4 hours. Up to Shirley some 8 or 9 miles further we went. Splendid country that. Noble hills and beautiful little ponds, in abundance. Excellent soil, those hills & few rocks, good crops & good markets. Moosehead you know. folks getting rich. Disappointed in Monson, hardly what it is cracked up: like up in woods better.
Some glorious scenery among hills.  We found some new plants there up. I brought home a species of Orchis. I think Virescens Bracteala of Bigelow, as described by Eaton, not down in Mrs. Lincoln. The Convallaria tribe puzzle me greatly, books dont do them justice, Lots of species of that or some analagous. I believe I have found out 1 or 2 by Eaton & Bigelow.
You must write soon & particularly, all how you get along etc. etc. what you do & how you board etc. etc. Tell Butters he promised to write Why dont he etc. What meeting is there, Always go to Church
Completed

Brunswick April 27th, 1845

Dear Brother

  I believe I shall not be able to thank you for my knowledge that you at Foxcroft, for you have taken no pains to let me sent to me, and moreover I received a letter from Milo, Apr. 25th, which mentions where you were etc. etc. but from their complaints, I gathered that you did not write more than once or twice oftener there than you have to me! I am afraid that you are not a very good hand to write letters to your brethren.
 I think that such Correspondence ought to be kept up. It is one most important method of keeping up, of preserving in all their freshness & fervor, of cultivating & strengthening, those feelings of friendship, fraternal affection & communion, which are certainly the best part of our poor human nature. The cultivation of the heart is no less important, than that of the mind. The affectionate interchange of thoughts & feelings, of joy & sorrow, of trials & pleasures, is the greatest, perhaps we might say almost the only source of all the happiness we have, which is purely sublunary. The pleasures of sense alone are and must ever be to the thinking mind - worthless- in comparison at least.

The others however could hardly be called of this world merely. They are so closely connected with those which take hold of another and a better, happier sphere.
Excuse this involuntary episode. I began upon the advantages of letter writing especially when friends & brothers are necessarily far separated. Surely  in such a subject, the mere expense, the postage, the paltry dimes, this world's drops, ought not to be considered, even though it were much more than it is. Even the intellectual advantage alone would much more than balance that.  Besides postage comes down. 

 I really want for the first thing that you should write me a full, great letter, about yourself, and all about Foxcroft.  You know I have lived there more than a year, and naturally feel interested there. My correspondents are there are not worth much, or not really ? I.G. Clark writes sometimes now, but you know, his letters are not much.
Completed

I wish you could just put Mr. Tash in mind of his duty in the way of writing to me: happen to mention receiving a letter from me,) I wondered he did not write & was hoping he would. I see the school is larger than ever before. How is Miss Smith? Write me about every body I know & every body I dont know. Who is that Chum of yours that talks politics so badly? How does Francis Mitchell? And the Chum who will come here next fall? & D. Anderson & N.S. Carpenter & old Chandler, Greely & Philbrick? Robinson, Smart etc. And the Ladies? -do you not get acquainted with them? you ought to. There are many there where acquaintance cannot but be profitable to any young man. If in any matter of conduct, I have erred to my heart, it has been in keeping myself from the society & acquaintance of the better sex, too much. You had chance to get acquainted with Sarah Holmes & Mary Tower & others last spring, but did not much, and I fear do not now. I believe they attend & Miss Carpenter & Hopkins & the Treats & others. Remember, now is the proper time of life to form acquaintances, and friends for life. Do you know the folks down to Cockran's? How is Mr. Parker this spring? I believe I must write to him soon. On what terms is Mr. Tash with him now?
Is there any interest on the subject of religion at Foxcroft, this spring?

 We do hope that the blessed Spirit of God has been granted to us somewhat here. There has been no excitement, but considerable seriousness, and it is  hoped some souls born into the kingdom of God.  About the time I returned, came one, who was much a rowdy last fall; he seemed very still, swore not; and it was soon whispered that 'Thornton" had experienced religion; Soon that others were serious, several of the 'best fellows' in College, & especially in our class.

Jasper Whiting, son of the commanding officer at Houlton, who is about the loveliest fellow I ever knew, The idol of our class, without an enemy, beloved by every one, excelling in every thing too, and as every one said 'so good', he went mourning about for two or three weeks, punctual every where, but with a countenance of deepest distress. When he smiled again, the joy that beamed from his eye was eloquent indeed. Many could not help thinking, that is 'the Major', as Whiting was always called, if he needed a change of heart, & was thus cast down for his sins, he who was, in the ideas of students - 'so good': when no one thought of ever having an ill feeling,
Completed

the best example of the amiability of the Natural heart, what must be the case with others.  It is hoped that some 4 or 5 others of our class have experienced a change of heart. and several others. Oh, the goodness of God! That He shall grant his Holy Spirit, & even count sinners, when those who professed to be His Servants, were so far from him, so much stumbling-blocks in the way of those who would enter in.

 The Lord has granted his Spirit again even to me. Oh how far, awfully far, I was from him, even if I had ever know him. How much I needed his converting spirit! and still need it!  I hardly know for how long I had not offered up one really sincere, hearty prayer to God. I do hope that God has converted me anew. Oh pray that these gracious influences may not be as the the morning cloud & the early dew alone, to my soul.
Joseph, will you not write me of your feelings. As brothers, as members of the same church, as both daring to trust in the same Redeemer of Sinners, we ought to be able to communicate our feelings freely to on another on every subject.
 I get along pretty well in my studies. French is easy, but we study it thoroughly. Trigonometry is pretty. I like it well & dont get screwed. Rhetoric we have finished studied it 'terribly.' Homer, Greek, I dont like quite so well comes hard to me. We write themes once a fortnight, begun this term. Declaim once a term.
 There is considerable doing here. I suppose two about the most elegant buildings in the state, going up this summer. They have begun upon our chapel & there are some 'acres of stones' in our yards. Chapel of solid Stone. 130 feet long 90 feet wide, with two solid towers, front 12 ft  rest of sentence is lost in fold of paper then taper. 3 Library rooms, 1 on end, and wings. The Chapel proper runs through between them. Gothic, long, narrow, extremely high, magnificently lighted only from above. stained glass, gothic windows. Planned by the greatest architect in the U.S. Upjohn of N. York. Church by the same, it is close by us, corner of college grounds. The old one, is already pulled down, stood for 10 years Bowd. first Commencement was held in it in 1806. Students glad to see it go. Their accommodations bad in it.
   Write soon. Get a bigger sheet of paper than this.            Aff. Brother Isaac.
Completed

Guess I shall be out the fall term if I can find any way to get money So look me a chance no matter what. School or anything. I am ready for anything. I shall be a "Junior" then, you know   Write   I.S.M.
